--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Usually when I deal with this type of thing I just
> make
> it so that no output can be illegal.  For example,
> in Go I consider an illegal move attempt by the
> network
> to be a requested pass.  That way a network that is
> otherwise
> good can still get its due credit, and might even
> learn
> to utilize its "criminal tendencies" to make
> rational decisions.
> For example, although the Go network does have a
> pass output,
> it may find it easier to instead pass by trying to
> place a piece
> on an already-occupied square.  Who is to say this
> is a bad
> way to communicate a pass if it gets the job done? 
> The point is to
> give the network as many opportunities to
> communicate valid moves
> as possible.

I agree with Ken that a "one strike and you're out"
selection pressure against illegal moves probably
isn't going to be very fruitful.

I like his approach of interpreting illegal moves as
passes.  I'd initially planned to approach Tic-Tac-Toe
and Gomoku (five-in-a-row) by simply ignoring illegal
outputs.

In TTT, there are nine output nodes corresponding to
board positions.  The game manager shows the ANN the
board and queries for a move, returning an array of
values for each board position.  If the highest output
value corresponds to an occupied space, the game
manager just takes the next highest output, and so on.

I don't know if this is the best approach (it's
certainly a lot more lax than killing them, or even
interpreting an illegal move as a pass), and I still
haven't done any experimentation with it.

Derek
